item.title: Elon Musk’s Boring Company Is in Talks With Government Over Amtrak Project
item.description: The Federal Railroad Administration has brought in the tunneling company to see if it could help with a multibillion-dollar rail project.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Mark Walker
item.media:description: The Boring Company facility in Bastrop, Texas. The Federal Railroad Administration has brought in the tunneling firm, founded by Elon Musk, to help with a multibillion-dollar Amtrak project.

item.title: For Trump, It’s a New Era of Deal-Making With Tech’s Most-Coveted Commodity
item.description: As the president heads to the Middle East, America’s dominance over A.I. chips has become a powerful source of leverage for the president.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: President Trump is touring the Middle East this week where he has strong business and financial ties. His administration appears to be interested in using artificial intelligence chips to secure strategic bonds in the region.

item.title: The Tech Guys Are Fighting. Literally.
item.description: Not content to battle it out in the boardroom, crypto bros, tech executives and start-up founders have embraced an old-fashioned version of masculinity.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew DeFeo
item.media:description: Andrew Batey, a venture capitalist, went to the annual cryptocurrency conference in Denver not to network with fellow crypto enthusiasts but to fight one of them.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Use of X Mimics Hearst’s and Ford’s Manipulation of Media
item.description: The Tesla billionaire is using his social media site X to rant and accuse. The politics of rage rarely worked out well for earlier moguls.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Anthony Gerace; Photograph by Joe Skipper/Reuters

item.title: Carvana, a Used Car Retailer, Thinks Tariffs Could be Good for Business
item.description: The chief executive of Carvana, which sells used cars online, said President Trump’s tariffs could help his company by increasing demand for its vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Carvana, an online seller of used cars, sees opportunity in high tariffs because it expects demand for used cars to climb.

item.title: Is Slate Auto’s Electric Truck the Answer to Expensive Cars?
item.description: Slate Auto, a start-up backed by Jeff Bezos, plans to sell a small, spartan electric truck that comes with no paint, stereo or touch-screens.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Ulrich

category.#text: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A model truck at Slate Auto’s design center in Troy, Mich. The company is backed by venture capital firms and Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder.

item.title: How the Columbia River Treaty Got Tangled in Trump’s Feud With Canada
item.description: Negotiations over the Columbia River basin could affect the environment in Canada and electrical generation and flood control in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Michael Hanson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Negotiations of a 60 year old treaty between Canada and United States regarding water rights in the Columbia River basin have stalled and could have large implications on flood control and hydroelectricity throughout the Pacific Northwest.

item.title: ‘The Interview’: Can Whitney Wolfe Herd Make Us Love Dating Apps Again?
item.description: The Bumble CEO has returned to run the struggling company she founded, and says she has a plan for getting Gen Z back.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Garcia-Navarro
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times

item.title: Google Agrees to Pay $1.4 Billion to Settle 2 Privacy Lawsuits
item.description: The Texas attorney general brought the cases in 2022 under state laws.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: A Google spokesman said, “This settles a raft of old claims, many of which have already been resolved elsewhere.”

item.title: Pinterest Agreed to Settle Christine Martinez Lawsuit for $34.7 Million
item.description: Christine Martinez, who was a friend of two of Pinterest’s three co-founders, sued the company in 2021 for breach of implied contract and other claims.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christine Martinez, who sued Pinterest in 2021, said Friday that she was “frankly just relieved to be past it.”

item.title: Teenager Fatally Shot During ‘Ding Dong Ditch’ TikTok Prank
item.description: A Virginia man was charged with second-degree murder after the shooting. The teenager’s friends told the authorities they had been filming a video of the prank for TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: A Decade-Long Search for a Battery That Can End the Gasoline Era
item.description: Can a small Massachusetts start-up perfect a battery that would make electric vehicles cheaper and more convenient than conventional cars?
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Factorial pilot factory in Methuen, Mass. To make money, a battery factory can’t produce too many defective cells.

item.title: Bad Apple, the Rise of the A.I. Empire and Italian Brain Rot
item.description: “I have rarely read a judge who is so obviously angry at a tech company.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Matt Collette, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Diane Wong
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photo: Getty Images

item.title: U.S. v. Google: What Both Sides Argued in a Hearing to Fix Its Search Monopoly
item.description: The Justice Department and Google have wrapped up a three-week hearing that could have a major impact on the search giant and how people gather information online.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:description: Judge Amit P. Mehta of U.S. District Court in Washington ruled in August that Google had acted as a monopoly in search.

item.title: How iPhone Apps Are Changing After a Recent App Store Ruling
item.description: A federal judge’s recent ruling has made it possible for apps to sell software and subscriptions outside the App Store without having to pay a commission.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: Last week a federal judge said that Apple must begin allowing apps to offer promotions and collect payments from users directly. This has included Amazon’s Kindle “Get Book” button in its app.

item.title: How Apple Created a Legal Mess When It Skirted Judge’s Ruling
item.description: Court documents show the company commissioned a sham report and lied on the stand to justify its actions, which will cast a shadow over future lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, and other executives were criticized in a federal judge’s ruling last week.

item.title: The 2006 Zuckerberg Quote at the Center of Meta’s Antitrust Trial
item.description: “Facebook is about real connections to actual friends,” Mark Zuckerberg said. Here’s why that could be a problem for Meta.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and chief executive of Meta, testifying at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing last year.

item.title: Elon Musk’s xAI in New Funding Talks
item.description: The discussions follow those of rival OpenAI, which recently closed a funding round that valued it at $300 billion.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: Elon Musk’s xAI is now intertwined with X, his social media company.

item.title: Bill Gates Explains His Plans to Close the Gates Foundation in 2045
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview, he explains his decision — amid the Trump administration’s assault on foreign aid — to accelerate the end of his giving.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

category.#text: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

item.media:credit: Katy Grannan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I think it’s objective to say to you that things will be better in the next 20 years.”

item.title: OpenAI Hires Instacart Chief Fidji Simo to Run Business and Operations
item.description: Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, said he hired Instacart’s Fidji Simo to join in a new role as chief executive of applications.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Fidji Simo, Instacart’s chief executive, is joining OpenAI as chief executive of applications.

item.title: Uber Revenue Is Up 14%, Despite Economic Fears
item.description: The company also predicted that business in the current quarter would be stronger than Wall Street had predicted.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan
item.media:description: Uber also announced a handful of new autonomous vehicle partnerships.

item.title: How to Use A.I.-Powered Writing Tools on Your iPhone and Android
item.description: Artificial intelligence software — some already free on your device — can quickly compose and edit documents. But be sure to check its work.
item.dc:creator: J. D. Biersdorfer
item.media:description: The writing tools in Apple Intelligence can compose, edit, condense and rewrite text for you, making it easier to draft documents on a smartphone or tablet with minimal typing or voice input.

item.title: NSO Group Ordered to Pay Meta $167 Million in Damages
item.description: Meta had sued the firm, NSO Group, for using its spyware to hack 1,400 WhatsApp accounts belonging to journalists, dissidents and others.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: An NSO Group office in Sapir, Israel. A spokesman for the company said it would pursue an appeal.

item.title: Elon Musk Tried Keeping Issues at His Texas Mansion Private, Emails Show
item.description: The tech billionaire’s staff was concerned that correspondence about his home in West Lake Hills would become public after neighbors complained.
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Grind
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A “No Trespassing” sign near Elon Musk’s properties in West Lake Hills, Texas.
